217. Coulter, (Mrs. Lewis Hanlin)
WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. L.H. Coulter
Address: Carleton
Birthplace: Stringfield, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1907
Where did you set up housekeeping? Bethune, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? Five
How far was it to your nearest store? Nine miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earlier years? Flour, sugar, lard, yeast cake, dried fruit, oatmeal cream of wheat, cornmeal

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lily and Magrath and Five Rose
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lb. sacks
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? 24¢
How much did you use Graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 20. That year? 1907
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 95¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes Whole wheat? No Farina? Yes
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
1. What year did you start homesteading? In Southern Canada? 1947.

   Where did you set up homestead? Blueberry Ranch.

   How far from Liviar before that? Conifer.

   For how many people did you prepare? Family.

   How far was it to your nearest store? About 4 miles.

   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week.

   What provisions did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, flour, dried fruit, oatmeal, cream, sugar, salt, evaporated milk, canned goods.

   What was the usual price per hundred? $2.50.

   Name what flour? Wheat flour.

   Was flour milled locally? Yes.

   What other grain products did you use? Corn meal.

   How did you grind it?

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.25.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwards.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At what price? $7.00.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Yes.

Eggs? Yes.

Butter? Yes.

What was the price of butter? 25¢.

Did you pack eggs for winter? No.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Wild game, beef, and pork.

How did you get fresh meat? Lived on our own.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Brine and smoke cured, also fried and covered with lard.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Rabbits, grouse, ducks.

For how long? First couple of years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not very prominent.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Pickerel, white fish, and suckers.

In what quantity did you buy milk? 20 lbs.

What was the price per lb.? $1.50

Did you purchase any other products? Yes

What kind of tea did you buy? Tuttle. At what price? $1.00.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground. Price? $3.00. What other beverages were used? Coffee.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.00. Did you get potatoes at the store? Yes. If not, where from? Raised our own.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1907. Cabbage Yes. Carrots Yes. Onions No.
Turnips No. Beets Yes.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lb.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box.
What weight? 25 lb. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...
What was the price of prunes? $1.25.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Dried apples, apricots, peaches, and fresh Saskatoon berries.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? Yes.
Other foods?

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1907.
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?
That year did you first preserve meat by canning?
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes, canning.

To what extent? 100 gal. per year.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

   What other dried fruits did you use in the last year? Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, lemons, raisins, currants, grapes, dates, figs, applesauce, applesauce sauce, and apple sauce.

9. CANNED FOODS:
   In the last year, how many cans of food did you buy? 10

10. PRESERVES:
    That year did you first preserve fruit? 1907
    How did you preserve it? By canning

    Did you ever make jam? No

16. **TRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

Mention any changes which you recall in the trappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Containers changed from wood to cardboard about 1910 to 1912.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast:** Porridge, Bacon or eggs, Potatoes fried
Coffee or tea, Toast and fruit

**Dinner:** Roast beef, potatoes boiled, cabbage or turnips
Pickled beets, custard apple or saskatoon pie
Tea or wild fowl or stuffed rabbit instead of beef

**Supper:** Scalloped potatoes cold meat Bread butter fruit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Roast tame chicken, scalloped potatoes, Dressing
Dill pickles, Steamed Pudding and home made candy. My father ages 60 my mother 50 my Butten 15
My husband 26 and myself 20.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1908 we lived for two weeks on flour made products and a pig's head and wild onions for two weeks or more. My husband was refused credit at one store but got a job of breaking to do for the owner of the store and took groceries for pay.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family or household.

Breakfast 1907: Porridge, Biscuits or Cake, Potatoes fried

Coffee or Tea, Toast and Jam, Cabbage or Turnips

Summer: Boiled Peas, Potatoes, Baked Beans, Cabbage or Turnips

Pickled Beets, Cucumbers, Pickled Onions

In 1908 we lived for two weeks on flour made from wild onions for two months and a pig's head and wild onions for two months or more. My husband was refused enlistment in the army but got a job of working to pay off the owner of the store and took groceries for pay.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

*Yeast makes bread in much less time.*
*Prepared foods such as jello, instant potatoes make for more variety and save much work.*

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

This has come gradually but we still use much of our home grown vegetables especially in summer and with the modern locker system we can have our own fresh meats.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

As we were near Regina and Moose Jaw we never were short of groceries except in the spring of 1907 when the railroads were blocked by snow. Coal was scarce but we were always able to get wood by driving fifteen to twenty miles and cutting our load of wood (over on section 37) My husband often left at five o'clock in the morning and returned at seven at night, but there was always a bush rabbit or two for dinner next day.

We could always get a supply of fish in the spring when they were going up the creek to spawn, these could be salted and used during the summer.
21. How did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of homegrown and homemade prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

This has become gradually but we still make our own much more now. We have grown our own vegetables in the garden and with the modern food system we can have our own fresh meats.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and preparing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada, including items not mentioned above, quality, methods of preparation, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

As we were near Regina and Brandon we were well ahead of everyone except in the spring of 1907 when the railroads were flooded by snow. Coal was scarce but we were always able to get wood by chopping fifteen to twenty miles and cutting our load of wood (over on Saturday). My husband often left at five o'clock in the morning and returned at seven or eight. But there were always a rush rabbit or two for dinner most days. The evening we could always get a supply of fresh in the evening when they were going off. We had to go down. They could be pulled and used during the summer.
He bought chickens and a pig on from Butten, which my husband bought from a little widow and we had eggs and meat and also he brought some no-hand milk, butter and other milk products all in all. They were good days with any little money but lots of good friends, happy living days, months and years. Forty four years and it almost seems like yesterday. But we are still old fashioned and they wrote us. So let's dig your grave with a card.

[Handwritten text not legible]
We bought chickens and a pig up from Ontario which my husband bought from a settler whose car came wrecked near Port Arthur so we had eggs and meat and also we brought cows so had milk, butter and other milk products. All in all they were good days with very little money but loads of good friends, happy busy days, months and years. Forty four years and it almost seems like yesterday. But we are still old fashioned and my motto is, Don't dig your grave with a can opener.
